BasicDescription.Title: Through The Night
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Jonathan Swain plays pieces by Gluck, Fodor, Mozart, Britten, Mozetich, Ponchielli, Donizetti, Kunileid, Couperin, Paganini, Rossini, Finzi, Turina, Duparc, Rossi, Handel and Holst.

With Jonathan Swain

BasicDescription.Title: Morning On 3
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Martin Handley plays Bach's Chaconne, Britten's Variations,Handel's Concerto, Dvorak's Golden Spinning Wheel, Shostakovich's Overture and Strauss' Till Eulenspiegel.

Presented by Martin Handley
6.10am Bach/Busoni: Chaconne in D minor (from Violin Partita No.2) Jorge Bolet (piano)
6.30am Britten: Variations on a theme by Frank Bridge English Chamber Orchestra Benjamin Britten (conductor)
7.00am Handel: Concerto grosso in F major, Op.3 No.4 Tafelmusik Jeanne Lamon (director)
7.35am Dvorak: The golden spinning wheel Czech Philharmonic Orchestra Jiri Belohlavek (conductor)
8.00am Shostakovich: Festive Overture The Philadelphia Orchestra Riccardo Muti (conductor)
8.40am Strauss: Til Eulenspiegels lustige Streiche The Cleveland Orchestra Christoph von Dohnanyi (conductor)

BasicDescription.Title: CD Review
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Andrew McGregor reviews new CDs and looks at Beethoven's Spring Sonata, new Rodrigo CDs and Donizetti's Lucia de Lammermoor, and interviews Paul Hillier.

With Andrew McGregor who plays some of this month's newest releases.
In Building a Library, Misha Donat compares the currently available recordings of Beethoven's Violin Sonata No.5, Op.24 Spring.
There's a round-up of some recently reissued recordings, David Huckvale reviews some recent recordings of Rodrigo's music, marking the close of his centenary year, and there's an interview with singer and choral director Paul Hillier, whose most recent recordings include the masses of William Byrd, and an anthology of choral music from the countries around the Baltic Sea.
Disc Of The Week:
Donizetti: Lucie De Lammermoor Natalie Dessay (Lucie) Roberto Alagna (Edgar) Orchestra & Chorus of Lyon National Opera, Evelino Pido (conductor)

BasicDescription.Title: Private Passions
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Michael Berkeley meets Nicholas de Jongh, chief theatre critic of the London Evening Standard, whose choice of music includes Bach, Schubert, Mozart, Richard Strauss and Mahler.

Today Michael Berkeley talks to Nicholas de Jongh, Chief Theatre Critic of The Evening Standard, and author of Politics, Prudery And Perversions, a history of the censorship imposed on the English stage from 1901 until 1968, when a row involving the plays of Edward Bond finally forced the Wilson government to abolish the practice.
Nicholas de Jongh's musical choices include a Bach cello suite, Schubert's Death and the Maiden String Quartet, a Mozart piano concerto, and the closing pages of Strauss' Elektra and Mahler's Ninth Symphony

BasicDescription.Title: World Routes
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Lucy Duran introduces sacred chant performed live in the studio by twenty Tibetan monks from Labrang monastery. Plus a round-up of new world music discs with Charlie Gillett.

Lucy Duran is joined live in the studio by a group of twenty Tibetan monks who are visiting the U.K for the first time. From the famous Labrang monastery in the frontier town of Xiahe, they bring with them conch shells, flutes, tuned cloud gongs, drums, mouth organs, and of course, their unique sacred chanting.
Plus a round-up of new releases on the world music scene with DJ Charlie Gillett.

BasicDescription.Title: Listeners' Choice
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Humphrey Carpenter introduces listeners' requests, including Delius' Piano Concerto, Debussy's Premiere Rapsodie and Arnold's Brass Quintet No 1.

Humphrey Carpenter introduces this week's selection of listeners requests, including:
Delius: Piano Concerto Benno Moisewitsch (piano) Philharmonia Orchestra Constant Lambert (conductor)
Debussy: Premiere Rapsodie for clarinet and orchestra Gervaise de Peyer (clarinet) BBC Symphony Orchestra Rudolf Kempe (conductor)
Arnold: Brass Quintet No.1 Center City Brass Quintet

BasicDescription.Title: Jazz Line-Up
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Claire Martin talks to singer Jane Monheit. Plus a round-up of new releases and gig news from around the country.

BasicDescription.Title: Jazz Record Requests
BasicDescription.Synopsis: With Geoffrey Smith. Request your favourite jazz cut by E mail: jazz.record.requests@bbc.co.uk

BasicDescription.Title: Jazz File
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The Dark Keys: Kevin Le Gendre explores the issue of race in the UK jazz scene in the second of two programmes.

The Dark Keys - Part Two
The concluding part of this series exploring the issue of race on the British Jazz scene.
Presenter Kevin Le Gendre looks at how welcoming the established London jazz clubs are to black musicians and examines the nature of Britain's jazz audiences: does the black community support its musicians, and does the black media give the music the profile it deserves?

BasicDescription.Title: Opera On 3
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The winter season of relays from the New York Met begins with Beethoven's Fidelio, starring Waltraud Meier, Johan Botha and Matti Salminen. Peter Schneider conducts.

Fidelio.
Beethoven's unique operatic hymn to freedom launches this winter's season of Radio 3 operas live from the Metropolitan Opera in New York. In one of the simplest and most moving of all opera plots, the heroine Leonora - disguised as a boy called Fidelio - strives to rescue her beloved husband Florestan from political imprisonment.
Leonore ...... Waltraud Meier (mezzo-soprano) Florestan ...... Johan Botha (tenor) Rocco, his gaoler ...... Matti Salminen (bass) Marzelline, Roccos daughter ...... Hei-Kyung Hong (soprano) Jaquino, the turnkey ...... Paul Charles Clarke (tenor) Don Pizarro, Florestans enemy ...... Richard Paul Fink (baritone) Don Fernando, Florestans boss ...... Alan Held (baritone)
Chorus and Orchestra of the New York Metropolitan Opera Conducted by Peter Schneider

BasicDescription.Title: The Met Opera Quiz
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Opera buffs pit their wits against teasers sent in by listeners. Brian Zeger is in the chair and the panel are Martin Bernheimer, Ken Benson and Alan Wagner.

BasicDescription.Title: Opera Snaps
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Rodney Milnes takes a sideways glance at tonight's opera: Beethoven's Fidelio.

BasicDescription.Title: Opera On 3
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Act 2 of Beethoven's Fidelio direct from the Metropolitan Opera, New York.

BasicDescription.Title: The Borodins Play Shostakovich
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The Borodin Quartet play Shostakovich's String Quartet No 9 at last year's Aldeburgh Festival.

BasicDescription.Title: The Verb
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Ian McMillan explores language, including a story by Nigerian Helon Habila, the University of East Anglia's creative writing course, and poet and storyteller Rosemary Harris.

This week in The Verb, Radio 3's international showcase of new writing, performance and language, there's a specially commissioned story by Helon Habila, the Nigerian novelist. He won acclaim -and the Caine Prize for African Writing - for his first novel Waiting for an Angel, about a young journalist living in one for the most dangerous cities in the world, Lagos under the military regime.
Habila has recently been on Britains best-known creative writing course at the University of East Anglia. The novelists Michele Roberts and Patricia Duncker are just reaching the end their first term as the two new professors running it and they submit their end of term report to the beady scrutiny of Ian McMillan, and introduce some voices to listen out for.
There's a performance piece from Rosemary Harris, a poet and storyteller from Australia who casts a pretty beady gaze on her society and ours too.
And Ian McMillan and his guests will consider the wonder and horror of language in the air, the language of the moment.

BasicDescription.Title: Hear And Now
BasicDescription.Synopsis: New music from this year's Huddersfield Festival by Danes Per Norgard and Pelle Gudmundsen-Holmgreen and by Billy Cowie, Simon Bainbridge, Joe Duddell and Stuart Macrae.

In the second programme from this year's Huddersfield Festival, Verity Sharp and Alwynne Pritchard introduce highlights from three concerts given by the BBC Singers, the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra and the Athelas ensemble.
The programme includes works by N�rg�rd, Cowie and Bainbridge and the world premieres of two BBC Commissions, Joe Duddell's Not Waving But Drowning and Stuart MacRae's Ancrene Wisse.
Plus, the first performance of the a cappella version of Duddell's The Real Side.
And from Denmark, the British premieres of Gudmundsen-Holmgreens and N�rg�rds R�ves en Plein Lumi�
